thread.title: Ex-AIG chief to pay $9M settlement in 12-year fraud lawsuit
thread.title_full: Ex-AIG chief to pay $9M settlement in 12-year fraud lawsuit

author: GLENN BLAIN
title: Ex-AIG chief to pay $9M settlement in 12-year fraud lawsuit
text:
Maurice (Hank) Greenberg, former Chairman and CEO of AIG, finally settles on a $9 million deal that closes a 12-year long accounting fraud lawsuit. (ChinaFotoPress/ChinaFotoPress via Getty Images) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Friday, February 10, 2017, 5:59 PM 
ALBANY — It only took a dozen years, but the State of New York has finally resolved its case with former AIG chairman Hank Greenberg. 
Attorney General Eric Schneiderman announced Friday afternoon that Greenberg will pay $9 million as part of a settlement that brings to a closed case first brought by then-Attorney General Eliot Spitzer in 2005. 
“Today's agreement settles the indisputable fact that Mr. Greenberg has denied for twelve years: that Mr. Greenberg orchestrated two transactions that fundamentally misrepresented AIG's finances,” Schneiderman said in a statement. 
As part of the settlement, Howard Smith, AIG's former Chief Financial Officer, will also pay $900,000 for his role in two fraudulent reinsurance transactions that were at the heart of the case. Attorney General Eric Schneiderman announced on Friday, Feb. 2, 2017 that Greenberg will pay a $9 million settlement to close the fraud case after 12 years. (Drew Angerer/Getty Images) 
Spitzer charged that AIG officials, led by Greenberg, overstated the company’s financial condition, including its loss reserves. AIG settled the case in 2006, paying $1.6 billion to the state. 
Greenberg repeatedly denied the allegations and continued to fight the case through two successive attorneys general. 
After a series of legal challenges brought by Greenberg’s legal team, the case finally went to trial last fall but the proceedings were recessed to allow time for both sides to negotiate a settlement with mediators Kenneth Feinberg and Camille Biros. Greenberg has managed to deny fraud allegations for 12 years and rotate through two attorney generals. (Craig Warga/Bloomberg) 
In addition to paying the $9 million, Greenberg had to admit his role in the bogus deals as part of the settlement. 
After bitter dispute, AIG agrees to give papers to former CEO Greenberg so he can write memoir 
“As a result of these transactions AIG’s publicly filed consolidated financial statements inaccurately portrayed the accounting, and thus the financial condition and performance for AIG’s loss reserves and underwriting income,” Greenberg said in a statement released by the attorney general as part of the deal. 
Greenberg’s attorney David Boies did not immediately respond to a request for comment. 
“After over a decade of delays, deflections, and denials by Mr. Greenberg, we are pleased that Mr. Greenberg has finally admitted to his role in these fraudulent transactions and will personally pay $9 million to the State of New York,” Schneiderman said. Join the Conversation:
